title: Linguistic Regularities in Continuous Space Word Representations
descriptions: This paper explores the linguistic regularities found in continuous space word representations learned by a recurrent neural network language model (RNNLM). The authors demonstrate that these word representations capture meaningful syntactic and semantic regularities in a simple manner, specifically observed as constant vector offsets between pairs of words sharing a particular relationship. The study utilizes a test set of analogy questions, covering various linguistic relationships, to evaluate the RNNLM's performance. The results show that the RNNLM outperforms other methods, such as LSA and Collobert and Weston's method, in capturing both syntactic and semantic regularities. Furthermore, the paper introduces a new dataset for measuring syntactic performance and achieves nearly 40% accuracy. Evaluation on the SemEval 2012 task also reveals that the RNNLM surpasses the previous state-of-the-art in semantic generalization. Notably, these results are achieved through an unsupervised maximum likelihood training criterion operating on a large text dataset.

This paper explores linguistic regularities in continuous space word representations, focusing on word vectors learned by a recurrent neural network language model (RNNLM). The study reveals that these representations capture meaningful syntactic and semantic regularities in a simple way, observed as constant vector offsets between pairs of words sharing a particular relationship. The authors evaluate the vector offset method using vectors generated by the RNN toolkit of Mikolov (2012) and compare it with other methods, such as LSA, Collobert and Weston (2008), and Mnih and Hinton (2009). Results show that the RNNLM word vectors capture significantly more syntactic regularity than LSA vectors and perform remarkably well in an absolute sense. The RNN-based representations also outperform previous systems in measuring semantic performance on the SemEval 2012 task. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed vector offset method for identifying linguistic regularities in continuous space word representations.

This study explores the linguistic regularities in continuous space word representations learned by a recurrent neural network language model (RNNLM). The model, trained to maximize data log-likelihood, induces word representations with striking syntactic and semantic properties. The authors evaluate the model's performance on syntactic and semantic tasks, formulated as analogy questions. They propose a simple vector offset method based on cosine distance, which assumes relationships are present as constant vector offsets in the embedding space. Experimental results show that the RNN vectors capture significantly more linguistic regularities than LSA vectors and perform remarkably well in an absolute sense. The study also introduces a new dataset for measuring syntactic performance and demonstrates that the RNN-based representations outperform previous state-of-the-art systems on the SemEval 2012 task for evaluating semantic generalization.

Surprisingly, these results are byproducts of an unsupervised maximum likelihood training criterion that operates on a large amount of text data.

The authors find that these representations capture meaningful syntactic and semantic regularities in a simple way, observed as constant vector offsets between pairs of words sharing a particular relationship. The study uses a test set of analogy questions to evaluate the syntactic regularities, and the SemEval 2012 task for semantic relations. Experimental results show that RNN vectors capture significantly more syntactic regularity than latent semantic analysis vectors and perform well in semantic generalization, outperforming the previous state-of-the-art. Remarkably, these results are achieved as a byproduct of an unsupervised maximum likelihood training criterion operating on a large amount of text data.

This paper explores linguistic regularities in continuous space word representations, specifically those learned by neural network language models. These models represent words as high-dimensional real-valued vectors, achieving a level of generalization not possible with classical n-gram language models. The study finds that the learned word representations capture meaningful syntactic and semantic regularities in a simple way, observed as constant vector offsets between pairs of words sharing a particular relationship. The authors use a recurrent neural network language model to obtain word vectors and evaluate their method using both syntactic and semantic tasks. Experimental results show that the proposed vector offset method based on cosine distance is effective in solving analogy questions, with RNN-based representations performing best in capturing linguistic regularities.
